annotations.html: Stanford psychology professor Dr. Carol Dweck is the internationally recognized pioneer of the concept of "growth mindset" as a way to continually grow, learn, and ① persist in our efforts. Dweck found that kids who are told they're "smart" actually ② outperform in future tasks, by choosing easier tasks to avoid evidence that they are not smart, which Dweck calls having a "fixed mindset." In contrast, Dweck found, kids who are praised not for their smarts but for their effort develop what Dweck calls a "③ growth mindset." They learn that their effort is what led to their success, and if they continue to try, over time they'll improve and achieve more things. These kids end up taking on ④ more challenging things, and feel better about themselves. "Emphasizing effort gives a child a variable that they can ⑤ manage," Dweck has explained.

annotations.html: We have a 'diving reflex', like other marine mammals. This means that special nerve endings on our faces, around the mouth and nose, trigger this reflex ① only when the facial region goes under water. If we are in the water, with our head out in the air, there is no diving reflex. But if we sink just our face in a bowl of water, while the whole of the rest of our body is in the dry air, the diving reflex is ② blocked. lt automatically closes down the airway, ③ reducing the risk of swallowing water, and it narrows the small air-passages in the lungs. At the same time the heart rate is slowed down to half speed and blood is shunted to the ④ vital organs, protecting them from the effects of the brief stop in breathing. By contrast, if a chimpanzee or a gorilla found itself in water with its face below the surface, it would panic, its heart would ⑤ race and it would quickly drown.

annotations.html: When you buy something with cash, the purchase involves an actual loss-your wallet is literally lighter. Credit cards, however, make the purchase ① abstract, so that you don't really feel the downside of spending money. Brainimaging experiments suggest that paying with credit cards actually reduces activity in the insula, a brain region associated with ② distressing feelings. As George Loewenstein, a neuroeconomist at Carnegie Mellon, says, "The nature of credit cards ensures that your brain is anesthetized against the pain of payment." Spending money doesn't feel bad, so you spend ③ additional money. Consider this experiment: Drazen Prelec and Duncan Simester, two business professors at MIT, organized a real life, sealedbid auction for tickets to a Boston Celtics game. Half the participants in the auction were informed that they had to pay with cash; the other half were told they had to pay with credit cards. Prelec and Simester then averaged the bids for the two different groups. lt turns out that the average credit card bid was half as ④ high as the average cash bid. When people used their credit cards, their bids were much more careless. They ⑤ no longer felt the need to limit their expenses.

It is natural for people to observe happenings and then seek explanations for why those happenings occurred. But sometimes the reasoning is wrong because of one or more misconceptions. One of these is the ecological fallacy, where an argument claims that there is a causal relationship between two things merely because they occur together. For example, in the 1950s it was found that crime rates were the highest in neighborhoods where immigrants were most numerous. Some people used this "co-occurrence" to argue that immigrants were a cause of crime. But a careful analysis of this situation revealed that immigrants were forced to live in neighborhoods where crime rates were already high; they could not afford more expensive housing in safer neighborhoods. lmmigrants themselves committed very few of the crimes.

Science is concerned with accumulating and understanding observations of the physical world. That understanding alone solves no problems. Individual people have to act on that understanding for it to help solve problems. For instance, science has found that regular exercise can lower your risk of heart disease. Knowing this fact is interesting, but it will do nothing for your personal health unless you act on it and actually exercise. And that's the hard part. Reading an article about exercise is easy. Getting into an actual routine of regular exercise is harder. In this sense, science really solves no problems at all. Problems are only solved when people take the knowledge provided by science and use it. In fact, many of humanity's biggest problems are caused by lack of action, and not lack of knowledge.

In everyday life, we use previous experience to predict where we should pay attention. Different environments create different expectations. He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. Were he to be tested on <u>such tasks</u>, he also would perform poorly.

When scientists make an important new discovery or experimentally prove some hypothesis, they do not, in general, keep that information to themselves so that they alone can consider its meaning and derive additional theories from it. Instead, they publish their results and make their data available for inspection. This makes it possible for other scientists to reconsider their data and possibly refute their conclusions. More important, though, it makes it possible for other scientists to use that data to construct new hypotheses and perform new experiments. The assumption is that society as a whole will end up knowing more if information is spread as widely as possible, rather than being limited to a few people. In a strict sense, every scientist depends on the work of other scientists.

People often ask me, "What surprises you most about habits?" One thing that continually astonishes me is the degree to which we're influenced by sheer convenience. The amount of effort, time, or decision making required by an action has a huge influence on habit formation. To a truly remarkable extent, we're more likely to do something if it's convenient, and less likely if it's not. For this reason, we should pay close attention to the convenience of any activity we want to make into a habit. Putting a wastebasket next to our front door made mail sorting slightly more convenient, and I stopped procrastinating with this chore. Many people report that they do a much better job of staying close to distant family members now that tools like group chats make it easy to stay in touch.

It is common sense that people's inner beliefs may drive their external behavior. If you're attracted to a certain person, you should be more likely to socialize with that person. If you favor a brand of toothpaste, you're more likely to buy it. Of course, our internal thoughts don't always predict our public behavior, but, overall, what we do obviously reflects what we think. But beliefs and behaviors are also related in a more remarkable way. It turns out that the arrow is as likely to point in the reverse direction. As social psychologist David Myers observes, "If social psychology has taught us anything during the last 25 years, it is that we are likely not only to think ourselves into a way of acting but also to act ourselves into a way of thinking."

Imagine following the spirit of a silence vow into daily life. Challenge yourself to spend an entire day saying only what you absolutely must say. lt's been widely observed by behavioral psychology experts — and anyone who's ever been on a first date—that we too often tend to treat "conversation" as a game of waiting for our own turn to speak. We miss what's being said because we're mentally rehearsing our next utterance. What if you could eliminate the idea that the next available mini–silence is your next opening to express whatever is in your head? What if you were limited to, say, fifty spoken words tomorrow? I think you'd listen quite differently. You'd attend quite carefully to every word you heard. You'd be attuned to what you must respond to. You might discover that the less you say, the more you hear.

Studies of experts provide insight into what it means to have deep and flexible understanding. Experts in a particular domain are people who have deep, richly interconnected ideas about the world. They are not just good thinkers or people who are exceptionally smart. Rather, experts have knowledge in a specific domain—such as chess, chemistry, or tennis —and are not generalists. However, experts do not just know "a bunch of facts." ln fact, having expertise in a topic means that knowledge is organized into coherent frameworks, and the expert understands the interrelationship between facts and can distinguish which ideas are most central. This kind of deep but organized understanding allows for greater flexibility in learning and facilitates application across multiple contexts.

It is natural for people to observe happenings and then seek explanations for why those happenings occurred. But sometimes the reasoning is wrong because of one or more misconceptions. One of these is the ecological fallacy, where an argument claims that there is a causal relationship between two things merely because they occur together. For example, in the 1950s it was found that crime rates were the highest in neighborhoods where immigrants were most numerous. Some people used this "co-occurrence" to argue that immigrants were a cause of crime. But a careful analysis of this situation revealed that immigrants were forced to live in neighborhoods where crime rates were already high; they could not afford more expensive housing in safer neighborhoods. Immigrants themselves committed very few of the crimes. Unless you analyze the claim carefully, you would misinterpret the relationship and thereby construct a faulty belief.

When you launch a new product or service, your priority should be to get sufficient market adoption as soon as possible and you should be ready to sacrifice your initial prices and profits to achieve this aim. Once you have strong sales volumes, you can increase your prices to maximize your profits.

In most respects, humans are one of a relatively small number of species that evolved a very different strategy of investing more energy to reproduce more slowly. Like apes and elephants, we mature at a leisurely pace, grow large bodies, and have few babies but devote much time and energy to raising them well. This unusual strategy succeeds because while apes and elephants produce fewer babies than mice, a larger percentage of their offspring survive to then reproduce. A house mouse can become a mother when she is just five weeks old, has four to ten pups per litter, and can have a new litter every two months over the course of her approximately twelvemonth life. However, the vast majority of her pups die young. In contrast, a chimp or elephant mother does not reproduce until she is at least twelve years old, and she gives birth to only one infant every five or six years over the next thirty or so years. About half of these offspring make it to becoming parents.

When scientists make an important new discovery or experimentally prove some hypothesis, they do not, in general, keep that information to themselves so that they alone can consider its meaning and derive additional theories from it. Instead, they publish their results and make their data available for inspection. This makes it possible for other scientists to reconsider their data and possibly refute their conclusions. More important, though, it makes it possible for other scientists to use that data to construct new hypotheses and perform new experiments. The assumption is that society as a whole will end up knowing more if information is spread as widely as possible, rather than being limited to a few people. In a strict sense, every scientist depends on the work of other scientists.

In the 1930s, the British psychologist Sir Frederic Bartlett asked people to listen to folktales from other countries and then recall these stories at a later date. As you might guess, unfamiliar stories were not remembered as well as familiar stories. Surprisingly, however, errors in memory were not random. Rather, subjects often rewrote similar parts of the stories in their own minds-particularly the parts that made the least sense to them. Bartlett concluded that when facing problems, humans draw upon mental schemata, or shelves of stored knowledge in our brains, to fill in any minor gaps in our memories. Therefore, remembering is an imaginative process that involves building upon past experiences.

History, people often say, repeats itself. And looking at the historical records of the ancient civilizations, some things do seem to happen again and again. Civilizations expand, get overextended, and then collapse as in the cases of Rome, which went under in 476 AD, and the British Empire, which fell apart more than a thousand years later in the post-World War $l l$ era. But is this always the case? If so, archaeology would be pretty boring; one thing would happen again and again. But that's not what archaeologists see. Some civilizations end suddenly, like the Aztec and Inca, conquered by invaders in the 1520s AD. Those empires never had the chance to collapse as a result of overexpansion. So in the case of civilizations, "history repeats itself" seems to be an oversimplification.

Stanford psychology professor Dr. Carol Dweck is the internationally recognized pioneer of the concept of "growth mindset" as a way to continually grow, learn, and persevere in our efforts. Dweck found that kids who are told they're "smart" actually underperform in future tasks, by choosing easier tasks to avoid evidence that they are not smart, which Dweck calls having a "fixed mindset." In contrast, Dweck found, kids who are praised not for their smarts but for their effort develop what Dweck calls a "growth mindset." They learn that their effort is what led to their success, and if they continue to try, over time they'll improve and achieve more things. These kids end up taking on tougher things, and feel better about themselves. "Emphasizing effort gives a child a variable that they can control," Dweck has explained.

To monitor our surroundings is to focus on what's outside of ourselves: what we see, hear, smell, feel, and perhaps even taste. But sometimes what really marks a place is something less specific — a feeling within us. An interesting example emerged from a study of subway passenger behavior. Researchers trying to understand why people sit where they sit or stand where they stand in subway and metro trains examined the factors that shape the way riders used and navigated that space in different situations. One of their findings involved the reasons many riders like to plant themselves close to the train's doors. Partly this was the obvious convenience of being able to exit more quickly. But it was shaped partly by a more abstract sensation — the desire to avoid the sometimes uncomfortable feeling of accidentally making eye contact with seated passengers. We can't see feelings—but they're very real, and they influence our experience of the world.

There is a natural assumption of truth, or a truth bias when humans communicate with one another. In other words, when we're listening to others or reading their words, our automatic assumption is that the other person is telling the truth. This usually works out fine. If you ask someone where the restroom is located or if it's raining outside, you can safely assume that most people will not lie in their responses. Imagine how difficult it would be to converse with someone if you assumed that everything they were telling you was false! Indeed, questioning the truth of a statement and then choosing not to believe it requires additional mental steps. For the most part, humans are "cognitive misers," which means we typically don't expend more mental effort than seems necessary in a given situation. It makes sense then, that when we see something online, even if it is fake, our default is to believe it, at least at first.

Science is concerned with accumulating and understanding observations of the physical world. That understanding alone solves no problems. Individual people have to act on that understanding for it to help solve problems. For instance, science has found that regular exercise can lower your risk of heart disease. Knowing this fact is interesting, but it will do nothing for your personal health unless you act on it and actually exercise. And that's the hard part. Reading an article about exercise is easy. Getting into an actual routine of regular exercise is harder. In this sense, science really solves no problems at all. Problems are only solved when people take the knowledge provided by science and use it. In fact, many of humanity's biggest problems are caused by lack of action, and not lack of knowledge.

In everyday life, we use previous experience to predict where we should pay attention. Different environments create different expectations. This was profoundly illustrated by the scientist Jared Diamond in his book Guns, Germs, and Steel. He describes an adventure wandering through the New Guinea jungle with native New Guineans. He relates that these natives tend to perform poorly at tasks Westerners have been trained to do since childhood. But they are hardly stupid. They can detect the most subtle changes in the jungle, good for following the tracks of a predator or for finding the way back home. They know which insects to leave alone, know where food exists, can build and tear down shelters with ease. Diamond, who had never spent time in such places, has no ability to pay attention to these things. Were he to be tested on such tasks, he also would perform poorly.

Most entrepreneurs put in tremendous amounts of time and effort in creating and launching new products and services and then make the mistake of overpricing them. They have created something they care deeply about, it's theirs, and this powerful sense of ownership distorts their perception of value which causes them to overprice their products. While many of them are quick to realize that their initial prices are too high, not all these people are happy or willing to drop their prices to make their products more attractive. And this can be a very costly mistake that may lead to the failure of their new business. When you launch a new product or service, your priority should be to get sufficient market adoption as soon as possible and you should be ready to sacrifice your initial prices and profits to achieve this aim. Once you have strong sales volumes, you can increase your prices to maximize your profits.

In most respects, humans are one of a relatively small number of species that evolved a very different strategy of investing more energy to reproduce more slowly. Like apes and elephants, we mature at a leisurely pace, grow large bodies, and have few babies but devote much time and energy to raising them well. This unusual strategy succeeds because while apes and elephants produce fewer babies than mice, a larger percentage of their offspring survive to then reproduce. A house mouse can become a mother when she is just five weeks old, has four to ten pups per litter, and can have a new litter every two months over the course of her approximately twelvemonth life. However, the vast majority of her pups die young. In contrast, a chimp or elephant mother does not reproduce until she is at least twelve years old, and she gives birth to only one infant every five or six years over the next thirty or so years. About half of these offspring make it to becoming parents.

When scientists make an important new discovery or experimentally prove some hypothesis, they do not, in general, keep that information to themselves so that they alone can consider its meaning and derive additional theories from it. Instead, they publish their results and make their data available for inspection. This makes it possible for other scientists to reconsider their data and possibly refute their conclusions. More important, though, it makes it possible for other scientists to use that data to construct new hypotheses and perform new experiments. The assumption is that society as a whole will end up knowing more if information is spread as widely as possible, rather than being limited to a few people. In a strict sense, every scientist depends on the work of other scientists.

Stanford psychology professor Dr. Carol Dweck is the internationally recognized pioneer of the concept of "growth mindset" as a way to continually grow, learn, and persevere in our efforts. Dweck found that kids who are told they're "smart" actually underperform in future tasks, by choosing easier tasks to avoid evidence that they are not smart, which Dweck calls having a "fixed mindset." In contrast, Dweck found, kids who are praised not for their smarts but for their effort develop what Dweck calls a "growth mindset." They learn that their effort is what led to their success, and if they continue to try, over time they'll improve and achieve more things. These kids end up taking on tougher things, and feel better about themselves. "Emphasizing effort gives a child a variable that they can control," Dweck has explained.

To monitor our surroundings is to focus on what's outside of ourselves: what we see, hear, smell, feel, and perhaps even taste. But sometimes what really marks a place is something less specific — a feeling within us. An interesting example emerged from a study of subway passenger behavior. Researchers trying to understand why people sit where they sit or stand where they stand in subway and metro trains examined the factors that shape the way riders used and navigated that space in different situations. One of their findings involved the reasons many riders like to plant themselves close to the train's doors. Partly this was the obvious convenience of being able to exit more quickly. But it was shaped partly by a more abstract sensation — the desire to avoid the sometimes uncomfortable feeling of accidentally making eye contact with seated passengers. We can't see feelings-but they're very real, and they influence our experience of the world.

We have a 'diving reflex', like other marine mammals. This means that special nerve endings on our faces, around the mouth and nose, trigger this reflex only when the facial region goes under water. If we are in the water, with our head out in the air, there is no diving reflex. But if we sink just our face in a bowl of water, while the whole of the rest of our body is in the dry air, the diving reflex is triggered. It automatically closes down the airway, reducing the risk of swallowing water, and it narrows the small air-passages in the lungs. At the same time the heart rate is slowed down to half speed and blood is shunted to the vital organs, protecting them from the effects of the brief stop in breathing. By contrast, if a chimpanzee or a gorilla found itself in water with its face below the surface, it would panic, its heart would race and it would quickly drown.

There is a natural assumption of truth, or a truth bias when humans communicate with one another. In other words, when we're listening to others or reading their words, our automatic assumption is that the other person is telling the truth. This usually works out fine. If you ask someone where the restroom is located or if it's raining outside, you can safely assume that most people will not lie in their responses. Imagine how difficult it would be to converse with someone if you assumed that everything they were telling you was false! Indeed, questioning the truth of a statement and then choosing not to believe it requires additional mental steps. For the most part, humans are "cognitive misers," which means we typically don't expend more mental effort than seems necessary in a given situation. It makes sense then, that when we see something online, even if it is fake, our default is to believe it, at least at first.

(A) At the same time the heart rate is slowed down to half speed and blood is shunted to the vital organs, protecting them from the effects of the brief stop in breathing.

(B) But if we sink just our face in a bowl of water, while the whole of the rest of our body is in the dry air, the diving reflex is triggered. It automatically closes down the airway, reducing the risk of swallowing water, and it narrows the small air-passages in the lungs.
(C) By contrast, if a chimpanzee or a gorilla found itself in water with its face below the surface, it would panic, its heart would race and it would quickly drown.

(①) For example, in the 1950s it was found that crime rates were the highest in neighborhoods where immigrants were most numerous. (②) But a careful analysis of this situation revealed that immigrants were forced to live in neighborhoods where crime rates were already high; they could not afford more expensive housing in safer neighborhoods. annotations.html: There is a natural assumption of truth, or a truth bias when humans communicate with one another. In other words, when we're listening to others or reading their words, our automatic assumption is that the other person is telling the truth. (①) This usually works out fine. (②) If you ask someone where the restroom is located or if it's raining outside, you can safely assume that most people will not lie in their responses. (③) Indeed, questioning the truth of a statement and then choosing not to believe it requires additional mental steps. (④) For the most part, humans are "cognitive misers," which means we typically don't expend more mental effort than seems necessary in a given situation. (⑤) It makes sense then, that when we see something online, even if it is fake, our default is to believe it, at least at first.

annotations.text: 밑줄 친 having expertise in a topic에 해당하지 <u>않는</u> 것을 <u>모두</u> 고르시오. (<u>2개</u>)

Studies of experts provide insight into what it means to have deep and flexible understanding. Experts in a particular domain are people who have deep, richly interconnected ideas about the world. They are not just good thinkers or people who are exceptionally smart. Rather, experts have knowledge in a specific domain—such as chess, chemistry, or tennis —and are not generalists. However, experts do not just know "a bunch of facts." In fact, <u>having expertise in a topic</u> means that knowledge is organized into coherent frameworks, and the expert understands the interrelationship between facts and can distinguish which ideas are most central. This kind of deep but organized understanding allows for greater flexibility in learning and facilitates application across multiple contexts.

Most entrepreneurs put in tremendous amounts of time and effort in creating and launching new products and services and then make the mistake of overpricing them. They have created something they care deeply about, it's theirs, and this powerful sense of ownership distorts their perception of value which causes them to overprice their products. While many of them are quick to realize that their initial prices are too high, not all these people are happy or willing to drop their prices to make their products more attractive. And this can be a very costly mistake that may lead to the failure of their new business. When you launch a new product or service, your priority should be to get sufficient market adoption as soon as possible and you should be ready to sacrifice your initial prices and profits to achieve this aim. Once you have strong sales volumes, you can increase your prices to maximize your profits.

In most respects, humans are one of a relatively small number of species that evolved a very different strategy of investing more energy to reproduce more slowly. Like apes and elephants, we mature at a leisurely pace, grow large bodies, and have few babies but devote much time and energy to raising them well. This unusual strategy succeeds because while apes and elephants produce fewer babies than mice, a larger percentage of their offspring survive to then reproduce. A house mouse can become a mother when she is just five weeks old, has four to ten pups per litter, and can have a new litter every two months over the course of her approximately twelve-month life. (A)__________, the vast majority of her pups die young. (B)__________, a chimp or elephant mother does not reproduce until she is at least twelve years old, and she gives birth to only one infant every five or six years over the next thirty or so years. About half of these offspring make it to becoming parents.

annotations.html: 밑줄 친 the diving reflex가 유발되는 경우에 해당하는 것의 기호를 쓰시오.
annotations.text: 밑줄 친 the diving reflex가 유발되는 경우에 해당하는 것의 기호를 쓰시오.

We have a '<u>diving reflex</u>', like other marine mammals. This means that special nerve endings on our faces, around the mouth and nose, trigger this reflex only when the facial region goes under water. If we are in the water, with our head out in the air, there is no diving reflex. But if we sink just our face in a bowl of water, while the whole of the rest of our body is in the dry air, the diving reflex is triggered. It automatically closes down the airway, reducing the risk of swallowing water, and it narrows the small air-passages in the lungs. At the same time the heart rate is slowed down to half speed and blood is shunted to the vital organs, protecting them from the effects of the brief stop in breathing. By contrast, if a chimpanzee or a gorilla found itself in water with its face below the surface, it would panic, its heart would race and it would quickly drown.

1. [정답] (3) which $\rightarrow$ where
[해설]
(3) 명사 areas를 수식하는 형용사절이며 완전한 절로 이어지므로 관계부사 where를 쓰는 것이 어법에 맞다.
(1) 5형식 동사 make의 목적격 보어 자리에 형용사를 쓴 것으로 어법상 적절하다. friendly는 -ly로 끝나는 "형용사"임에 유의한다.
(2) 공원이 '설계된' 것을 수동태로 나타낸 것이므로 어법상 옳다.
(4) 목적(~하기 위해)을 나타내는 to부정사의 부사적 용법 쓰임이다.
(5) 어순 : [한정사(this) + 부사(newly) + 형용사/분사(opened) + 명사]
2. [정답] (3) has left $\rightarrow$ had left
[해설]
(3) 여권을 집에 놓고 온 것은 과거(공항 상황) 이전에 대한 내용 이므로 과거완료 시제를 써야 한다.
(1) 핵심 주어가 her expectations로 복수 명사이므로 복수 동사 형태가 어법에 맞다.
(2) can’t wait + to부정사 : 너무 ~하고 싶다
(4) 계획이 '망쳐졌다'는 의미이므로 수동태 형태가 어법에 맞다.
(5) 분사구문이며 주절의 주어(She)와 능동 관계이므로 현재분사 형태가 어법상 적절하다.
3. [정답] (2), (5)
[해설]
(2) 핵심 주어가 The amount로 단수 명사이므로 단수 동사가 옳다.
(5) 5 형식 동사 make의 가목적어로 it을 쓴 것은 어법에 맞다.
(1) 명사 the degree를 수식하는 형용사절이며 완전한 절로 이어지므로 [전치사 + 관계대명사 (to which)]를 써야 한다.
(3) '편리하지 않다면'을 의미하는 대동사를 써야 하므로 isn't가 어법에 맞다.
(4) 5형식 동사 make의 목적격 보어 자리이므로 형용사 형태를 써야 한다.

4. [정답] (3)
[해설]
(3) 동사 reflects의 목적어 자리에 명사절을 쓰는 부분으로 선행사를 포함하고 목적어 역할을 하는 관계대명사 what을 써야 한다.
(참고) 접속사 that을 쓰면 '우리가 생각한다는 것을 반영한다'는 의미가 되어 글의 흐름에 적절하지 않다.
(1) 진주어에 해당하는 부분으로 접속사 that은 어법에 맞다.
(2) '~일 것이다'는 의미를 나타내는 should의 쓰임(가능성을 나타냄) 으로 어법에 맞다.
(4) be likely to: ~일 것 같다 / as : equally, to the same degree를 의미하여 ‘화살이 반대 방향을 가리킬 가능성이 그만큼 높다’는 내용을 나타낸다.
(5) not only A but also B에 의해 to think, to act가 병렬 구조 로 연결된 부분이다.
5. [정답] (2)
[해설]
(2) 가주어 lt을 설명하는 진주어 부분으로 접속사 that을 쓰는 것이 어법에 맞다.
(1) [spend + 시간 ~ing] : ~하는 데 시간을 보내다
(3) 관계대명사 what, 현재진행 시제, 수동태를 쓴 부분으로 '말해지고 있는 것이라는 의미를 나타내는 부분이다.

(5) 선행사를 포함하고, 전치사 to의 목적어 역할을 하는 관계대명사 what으로 어법상 적절하다.

[해설]
(2) [동사 help + 동사원형/to부정사] 형태로 쓴다.

(3) 시간의 부사절에서는 현재시제로 미래를 나타내므로 어법상 적절하다.
(4) [Only ~ + 동사 + 주어] 도치된 형태로 어법상 옳다.

[A] ‘부분적으로’ 실명했다는 의미로 동사를 수식하므로 부사 형태를 쓰는 것이 어법에 맞다.
[B] 장소 명사를 수식하며 완전한 절로 이어지므로 관계부사 where 를 쓴다.
[C] 상을 받았다는 의미로 동사 win(~을 얻다)을 타동사 형태로 쓴다. (참고) award는 '수여하다'는 의미로 그가 상을 받은 것이므로 was awarded 형태로 써야 한다.

(1) 가주어 it 뒤에 진주어를 나타내는 부분으로 to부정사는 옳다.
(2) 핵심 주어가 Experts로 복수 명사이므로 복수 동사가 어법에 맞다.
(4) [의문 형용사(which) + 명사] 형태로 어법상 적절하다.

(5) 분사구문이며 앞 절 전체 내용의 추가 설명을 나타내는 부분으로 어법상 적절하다.

11. [정답] (2) which $\rightarrow$ where (4) forced $\rightarrow$ were forced [해설]
(2) ecological fallacy를 설명하는 형용사절이며 완전한 절로 이어지므로 관계부사 where를 써야 한다. 관계부사 where는 구체적인 장소 명사 이외에도 넓은 개념으로 사용되기도 한다.
(4) 이민자들이 '강요받았다'는 의미이므로 수동태 형태로 써야 한다.
(1) 전치사 for 뒤 명사절 부분으로 의문사 why를 쓴 것이다.
(3) 명사 neighborhoods를 수식하는 형용사절이며 완전한 절로 이어지 므로 전치사+관계대명사 in which 또는 관계부사 where를 쓸 수 있다.
(5) 재귀대명사의 강조 용법으로 어법상 적절하다.

[이전 문장] 한 가지 일이 반복해서 일어난다면 고고학은 지루할 것
[이 문장] 하지만 그것은 고고학자들이 보는 것이 아님
[다음 문장] 어떤 문명들은 아즈텍, 잉카처럼 갑작스럽게 끝남 (반복 되는 패턴이 아닌 역사의 예시)
142. [정답] (3)
[해설]
[이전 문장] 노력에 대한 칭찬을 받은 아이들은 성장 사고방식을 발달 시킴
[이 문장] 그들은 (성장 사고방식을 발달시킨 아이들) 노력이 성공으로 이르게 한 것임을 배우고 시간이 지나면서 더 발전하고 성취할 것
[다음 문장] 이 아이들은 결국 더 힘든 일을 받아들이고 스스로에 대해 더 좋은 느낌을 갖게 됨
143. [정답] (4)
[해설]
[이전 문장] 문 근처 자리를 좋아하는 부분적 이유는 빨리 내릴 수 있는 명확한 편리함 때문
[이 문장] 그러나 추상적 느낌 (다른 승객과 눈 마주치는 불편한 느낌을 피하려는 것)도 부분적인 이유가 됨
[다음 문장] 감정을 볼 수는 없지만 우리 경험에 영향을 미침
144. [정답] (4)
[해설]
[이전 문장] 잠수 반사는 기도를 자동으로 닫고 폐 속 공기 통로를 좁힘
[이 문장] 동시에 심박수, 혈액 흐름도 바꿔 짧은 호흡 정지로 인한 영향 으로부터 보호
[다음 문장] 반면 침팬지나 고릴라는 잠수 반사가 없음
145. [정답] (3)
[해설]
[이전 문장] 일상 상황에서 대부분 사람들의 응답을 확신하며 믿을 수 있음
[이 문장] 사람들이 말하는 모든 것이 거짓이라고 가정하면 대화가 힘들 것
[다음 문장] 진실성에 의문을 제기하고 믿지 않는 것을 선택하는 것 은 정신적 노력을 더 필요로 함

146. [정답] (1), (4)
[해설]
(1) 전문가가 많은 사실만 아는 것은 아니라고 했으며
(4) 유난히 똑똑한 사람인 것만은 아니라고 했다.
147. [정답] (A) prioritize (B) sacrificing
148. [정답] (1)
[해설]
[A] 생쥐가 성장, 번식 속도가 빠르지만 (However) 새끼들의 대부분이 어릴 때 죽는다는 내용이 흐름에 어울린다.
[B] 생쥐의 경우와는 반대로 (ln contrast) 침팬지나 코끼리는 번식 속도는 느리지만 새끼의 생존률이 높다는 내용으로 이어진다.
149. [정답] (2)
[해설]
[A] 추측할 수 있듯이 친숙하지 않은 이야기는 잘 기억되지 않았지만 (however) 오류가 무작위가 아니었다는 내용이 흐름에 어울린다.
[B] 우리가 문제에 직면하면 기억의 틈을 메우기 위해 저장된 지식을 활용 한다고 했음로 (Therefore) 기억하는 것은 과거 경험을 기반으로 하는 상상의 과정이라고 하는 것이 적절하다.
150. [정답] (a), (c)
[해설]
(a) 해양 포유류처럼 인간이 잠수 반사를 가지고 있다고 했으모 해양 포유류는 잠수 반사가 나타난다.
(c) 얼굴이 물 속에 있을 때 잠수 반사가 나타난다고 했음로 몸은 밖 에 있지만 얼굴이 물 속에 있으면 잠수 반사가 나타난다.
151. [정답] (2)
[해설]
[A] 인간은 진실 편향이 있다는 말을 다시 말해(ln other words) 뒤에 다시 설명하는 부분이다.
[B] 사람들이 하는 말이 모두 거짓이라고 가정하면 대화가 얼마나 어려울지 상상해 보라는 가정 뒤에 정말로(Indeed) 진실성에 의문을 제기하고 믿지 않는 선택을 하는 것은 정신적 노력을 더 필요로 한다고 하는 것이 적절하다.

152. [정답] (4)
[해설]
[A] 전문가는 단순히 똑똑한 사람이 아니라 오히려(Rather) 특정 분야 지식을 가지고 다방면의 지식을 가진 사람이 아니라고 하는 것이 적절하다.
[B] 사람들이 하는 말이 모두 거짓이라고 가정하면 대화가 얼마나 어려울지 상상해 보라는 가정 뒤에 정말로(lndeed) 진실성에 의문을 제기하고 믿지 않는 선택을 하는 것은 정신적 노력을 더 필요로 한다고 하는 것이 적절하다.
153. [정답] (5)
[해설]
[A] 머리는 공기 중에 있는 상태로 물속에 있으면 잠수 반사가 없지만 (However) 몸 전체가 공기 중에 있지만 얼굴이 물속에 있으면 잠수 반사가 있다고 하는 것이 적절하다.
[B] 사람의 잠수 반사를 설명한 뒤 반면(By contrast) 침팬지나 고릴라 는 잠수 반사가 없다는 내용이 나오는 것이 적절하다.

- The End :) -

annotations.html:
[제시문] 사건에 대한 이유를 찾는 것은 당연하지만 추론이 잘못되기도 함
(A) 잘못된 추론 중 하나로 생태학적 오류 제시 (동시 발생을 인과관계로 잘못 판단하는 것)
(C) 이민자들 사례 : 이민자가 많은 지역에 범죄율이 높으므로 이민자들이 범죄의 원인이라는 주장
(B) 하지만 면밀한 상황분석은 이민자들이 이미 범죄율이 높은 지역에 거주할 수밖에 없었던 것을 밝힘

annotations.html:
[해설]
[제시문] 우리는 이전 경험을 사용하여 집중할 분야을 예측함. Diamond의 정글 모험 예시
(B) 그는 원주민들은 서구인들이 훈련받아 온 과업을 잘 수행하지 못하지만 멍청한 것은 아니라고 말함
(C) 원주민들의 정글 생존 능력과 기술들 예시 (그들에게 필요한 능력 뛰어남)
(A) 그런 과업(정글 생존)에 주의를 기울인 적 없는 Diamond는 그런 과업을 잘하지 못함

[해설]
[제시문] 과학자들은 새로운 발견을 자기만 가지고 있지 않음
(B) 대신에 결과를 발표하여 다른 과학자들이 재고, 반박 등을 하도록 함
(A) 하지만 더 중요한 것은 그 데이터를 사용하여 다른 과학자들이 새로운 연구를 하도록 하는 것
(C) 가정은 정보가 확산되면 사회 전체가 많은 것을 알게 된다는 것이고 모든 과학자는 다른 과학자의 연구에 의존한다고 할 수 있음

annotations.html:
[해설]
[제시문] Bartlett의 실험에서 낯선 이야기를 듣고 기억하라고 했을 때 오류가 무작위가 아니었음
(C) 오히려 피험자들은 비슷한 부분을 다시 썼음 (무작위 아닌 것)
(A) 이를 통해 Bartlett은 인간이 문제에 직면하면 기억의 틈을 메우기 위해 저장된 지식을 활용한다고 결론 내림
(B) 따라서 기억은 과거 경험을 기반으로 하는 것을 포함한 상상의 과정임
